MeshNumber = | Code = | }} 'Brown adipose tissue' ('BAT') or 'brown fat' is one
of two types of fat or adipose tissue (the other being white adipose tissue)
found in mammals.

It is especially abundant in newborns and in hibernating mammals. Its primary function is to generate body heat in
animals or newborns that do not shiver. In contrast to white adipocytes (fat
cells), which contain a single lipid droplet, brown adipocytes contain numerous
smaller droplets and a much higher number of (iron containing) mitochondria,
which make it brown. Brown fat also contains
more capillaries than white fat, since it has a greater need for oxygen than
most tissues.
